text: Genesis chapter 46 and we are making progress through the book of Genesis. Amen. There's only 50 chapters. We are near the end and this evening is message number 94. And so if you've been here for the study through the book of Genesis, this is the 94th sermon that I have preached from the book of Genesis. I have thoroughly enjoyed it. I've been encouraged, strengthened and challenged. I trust that you have as well. By God's grace and with God's help, we'll look at the entirety of Genesis 46 this evening. There's 34 verses. I do not plan to read all of them. We'll make reference to all of them. But notice, if you will, beginning in verse number one of Genesis 46, the Bible says, And Israel took his journey with all that he had and came to Beersheba and offered sacrifices unto the God of his father Isaac. And God spake unto Israel in the visions of the night and said, Jacob, Jacob. And he said, Here am I. And he said, God said, I am God, the God of thy father. Fear not to go down into Egypt, for I will there make of thee a great nation. I will go down with thee into Egypt, and I will also surely bring thee up again. And Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes. Before we dig into chapter 46, very quickly a review of chapter 45 that we studied two weeks ago. We find that it's in Genesis chapter 45 that the record is provided to us where Joseph reveals his identity to his brothers. Of course, we know that there was a series of events that led up to this revelation. And Joseph, as he revealed himself to his brothers, he explains to his brothers the duration of that great famine. He says there's only been two years of famine, and there's going to be a total of seven, so there's five more years of famine. And we find that he also discloses to his brothers the purpose that God had in sending him to Egypt. In fact, Joseph made it very plain in Genesis 45 as he reveals his perspective of life and understanding that God is in control. And though the brothers had sold him into slavery, he says, God sent me. God sent me before you for this purpose of preserving life. And we find that as Joseph had an opportunity to reveal himself and reveal his perspective, he then gives to his brothers a plan. The plan included returning back home and bringing all of the provision that had been provided and letting his father know that he was still alive. And then, not to stay in the homeland, but to return. And he tells them that as they would return back to Egypt, that it was there that Joseph would care for them. What a gracious, gracious chapter that we read of and begin to see the picture of forgiveness and restoration and reconciliation. And what a blessing. The chapter ends, chapter number 45, it ends with the brothers arriving. And no doubt, as Jacob was awaiting their return and his anticipation was that they were coming back with food, with sustenance, because there was a great famine and they needed food. But yet, we find that he would see that there was a great host and all of the wagons and so on and so forth. And they hear the news, they deliver the news to Jacob that Joseph is alive. It's absolutely amazing as you see that the Bible tells us in verse 27 that the spirit of Jacob, their father, revived. I mean, this is an amazing account. And he says, it is enough. Joseph, my son, is yet alive. I will go and see him before I die. In Genesis chapter 46, the passage in which we'll be studying this evening, really the highlight of the entire chapter is the reunion between Jacob and his son Joseph. As we begin to dig into this passage of scripture, I want you to see just a few thoughts tonight. Number one, if you're taking notes, and I've titled the message this, a family reunion, a family reunion. Notice with me, if you will, number one, promises for the journey. Understand with me that Jacob and the family, they were going to take a journey and we find that as they would take this journey that God meets with Jacob and God gives Jacob some promises. I'm so thankful for the promises of God. We sing, standing on his promises. We understand that God's word is full of great promises. In fact, Peter says that they're exceeding great and precious promises in 2 Peter 1 and verse number 4. And we think about all the wonderful promises of God and we come to this passage of scripture and we understand that there's this journey that's going to take place. But before the journey is even started, we find that God appears to Jacob and God gives him some promises. Promises for the journey. I am God. Isn't that amazing? To understand who he is, to understand that he is the creator God, that he is the sustainer, he is the giver of life, he is the omnipotent one, he is the God of the impossible, and he says to Jacob, I am God. And so we find that as Jacob is receiving this vision from the Lord, that God tells him that there's no need to fear. Now that seems to indicate to me that God, knowing all things new, that within the heart of Jacob, there was an element of fear. There was a aspect in this journey that was causing him to fear. God gave a promise to Jacob in this passage of Scripture, promises for the journey, and he says, I will there make of thee a great nation. Where is there? Well, Egypt, the place in which Jacob and his family would be traveling to, and he says, I will there make of thee a great nation. What a great promise that God gives. And by the way, it's only God that can make such a promise. It's only God that can speak with regard to the future, because he knows all things. He's outside of the realm of time. He's speaking in the future tense of what God will do. By the way, he's the giver of life, and he's the one that can say, I will make of thee a great nation, and he's made this promise. We find that he does not end there. Notice in verse number four, he says, I will go down with thee into Egypt. I want you to think about the significance of this promise in verse number four, when he speaks about his presence being with Jacob. What a joy it is to know the presence of the Lord. What a joy. The psalmist says that in his presence is fullness of joy. We have the promise, as New Testament believers, we often run to in Hebrews 13, where God said, I will never leave thee nor forsake thee. And here, as Jacob is embarking on this journey, and he's preparing to lead his family, God appears to him, and God gives him some promises for the journey. He says, I'm going to be with you. I'm going to build, I'm going to make of thee a great nation there in Egypt, but he says, I will go down with thee into Egypt. And then notice he says in verse number four, and I will also surely bring thee up again. And I want you to notice the end of verse number four, when he says this, and Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes. This evening, as I consider promises for the journey for Jacob in verses one through four of Genesis 46, I'm reminded this evening that you and I are on a journey. It's a journey that we often call life. We understand that on this journey of life, that there are valleys and there are mountains. There are times of blessing and there are times in which we seem as if it's just a time of difficulty, a time of uncertainty. And we find that God has given us promises for the journey.
